00017 =head1 NAME
00018 
00019 answerCustom.pl - An easy method for creating answer checkers with a custom
00020 subroutine that performs the check for correctness.
00021 
00022 =cut
00023 
00024 loadMacros('MathObjects.pl');
00025 
00026 sub _answerCustom_init {}; # don't reload this file
00027 
00028 =head1 MACROS
00029 
00030 =head2 custom_cmp
00031 
00032     ANS(custom_cmp($correct_ans, $ans_checker, %options))
00033 
00034 This answer checker provides an easy method for creating an answer
00035 checker with a custom subroutine that performs the check for
00036 correctness.
00037 
00038 Pass the correct answer (either as a string or as a Parser object)
00039 as the first argument, and a reference to the checker subroutine
00040 as the second argument.  Additional parameters can follow.  These
00041 include any of the parameters for the usual answer checker of the
00042 of the type of the correct answer (e.g., showCoordinateHints), plus
00043 the following:
00044 
00045 =over
00046 
00047 =item S<C<< sameClass => 0 or 1 >>>
00048 
00049 If 1 (the default), only call the
00050 custom checker if the student answer
00051 is the same object class as the correct
00052 answer (e.g., both are points).
00053 If 0, the checker will be called
00054 whenever the student answer passes
00055 the typeMatch check for the correct
00056 answer.  For example, if the correct
00057 answer is a vector, and promotePoints
00058 has been set to 1, then the checker
00059 will be called when the student answer
00060 is a vector OR a point.
00061 
00062 =item S<C<< sameLength => 0 or 1 >>>
00063 
00064 If 1 (the default), only call the
00065 custom checker if the student answer
00066 has the same number of coordinates as
00067 the correct answer.
00068 
00069 =back
00070 
00071 If the correct answer is a list, the custom checker will be called
00072 on the individual entries of the list, not on the list as a whole.
00073 If the list is an unordered list, the routine may be called
00074 multiple times with various combinations of student and professor's
00075 answers in order to find a correct match.
00076 
00077 Note: If you want a correct answer whose class is a complex variable
00078 to check a real number entry you will have to set both sameClass and
00079 sameLength to 0 since a complex number has length 2 and a real number
00080 has length 1.
00081 
00082 The checker routine will be passed the correct answer, the
00083 student's answer, and the answer evaluator object, in that order.
00084 
00085 For example, the following checks if a student entered
00086 a unit vector (any unit vector in R^3 will do):
00087 
00088     ANS(custom_cmp("<1,0,0>",sub {
00089         my ($correct,$student,$ans) = @_;
00090         return norm($student) == 1;
00091     },showCoordinateHints => 0));
00092 
00093 The checker subroutine can call Value::Error(message) to generate
00094 an error message that will be reported in the table at the top of
00095 the page.  If the checker generates a fatal runtime error (e.g.,
00096 calls the "die" function), then the message is reported with the
00097 "pink screen of death", and includes a request for the student to
00098 inform the instructor.
00099 
00100 =cut
00101 
00102 sub custom_cmp {
00103   my $correct = shift; my $checker = shift;
00104   die "custom_cmp requires a correct answer" unless defined($correct);
00105   die "custom_cmp requires a checker subroutine" unless defined($checker);
00106   $correct = Value::makeValue($correct);
00107   $correct = Value->Package("Formula")->new($correct) unless Value::isValue($correct);
00108   $correct->cmp(
00109     checker => sub {
00110       my ($correct,$student,$ans) = @_;
00111       return 0 if $ans->{sameClass} && $correct->class ne $student->class;
00112       return 0 if $ans->{sameLength} && $correct->length != $student->length;
00113       return &{$ans->{custom_checker}}($correct,$student,$ans);
00114     },
00115     custom_checker => $checker,
00116     sameClass => 1,
00117     sameLength => 1,
00118     showEqualErrors => 1,  # make sure we see errors in list checker
00119     @custom_cmp_defaults,
00120     @_,
00121   );
00122 }
00123 
00124 #
00125 #  Set this to include any default parameters you want
00126 #  to include in the custom answer checkers
00127 #
00128 @custom_cmp_defaults = ();
00129 
00130 =head2 custom_list_cmp
00131 
00132  ANS(custom_list_cmp($correct_ans, $ans_checker, %options))
00133 
00134 This one installs a custom list-based answer checker (for the
00135 List and Union classes).  Basically it is just a shell that makes
00136 it a little easier to do, and provides an interface similar to 
00137 custom_cmp.
00138 
00139 You pass the correct answer (as a string or as a List or Union
00140 object) as the first argument, and the custom list checker as
00141 the second argument.  You can pass any additional parameters
00142 that should be included in the answer checker following those
00143 two required ones.
00144 
00145 The checker will be passed a reference to the array of correct
00146 answers, a reference to the array of student answers, and
00147 the answer evaluator object.  Note that the correct and student
00148 answers are array references, not List structures (this is because
00149 a list of formulas becomes a formula returning a list, so in order
00150 to keep the formulas separate, they are passed in an array).
00151 
00152 The checker should return the number of list entries that were
00153 matched by the students answers.  (I.e., a number between 0
00154 and the length of the list.)
00155 
00156 For example, the following checks for any list of the same length
00157 as the instructor's list.  (A stupid checker, but just an example.)
00158 
00159     ANS(custom_list_cmp("1,2,3",sub {
00160         my ($correct,$student,$ans) = @_;
00161         (scalar(@{$correct}) == scalar(@{$student}) ? 3 : 0);
00162     }));
00163 
00164 The checker subroutine can call Value::Error(message) to generate
00165 an error message that will be reported in the table at the top of
00166 the page.  If the checker generates a fatal runtime error (e.g.,
00167 calls the "die" function), then the message is reported with the
00168 "pink screen of death", and includes a request for the student to
00169 inform the instructor.
00170 
00171 =cut
00172 
00173 sub custom_list_cmp {
00174   my $correct = shift; my $checker = shift;
00175   die "custom_list_cmp requires a correct answer" unless defined($correct);
00176   die "custom_list_cmp requires a checker subroutine" unless defined($checker);
00177   $correct = Value::makeValue($correct);
00178   $correct = Value->Package("Formula")->new($correct) unless Value::isValue($correct);
00179   $correct->cmp(
00180     list_checker => $checker,
00181     @custom_list_cmp_defaults,
00182     @_,
00183   );
00184 }
00185 
00186 #
00187 #  Set this to include any default parameters you want
00188 #  to include in the custom answer checkers
00189 #
00190 @custom_list_cmp_defaults = ();
